properties.name: Zaporizhzhia
properties.photo1_cap:
Aerial image of the six reactors at Zaporozhzhia nuclear plant, showing dry spent fuel storage area (centre) where two artillery shells found.
Source: Satellite image ©2022 Maxar Technologies. Photo taken Nov. 2, 2019.
properties.photo2_cap:
Heavy weapons fire from the rear of the Russian column flew in the direction of the Zaporozhzhia Unit 1 reactor building.
Credit: Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant. Annotations by NPR.
properties.photo3_cap:
Heavy weapons fire from the rear of the Russian column flew in the direction of the Zaporozhzhia Unit 1 reactor building.
Credit: Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant. Annotations by NPR.
properties.photo4_cap:
Above - hole in roof of walkway that runs parallel to the six reactor units.
Credit: Energoatom/Telegram
properties.photo5_cap:
Artillery shell on floor of walkway that runs parallel to the six reactors at Zaporozhzhia.
Credit: Energoatom/Telegram
properties.report: The vulnerability of nuclear plants during military conflict: Lessons from Fukushima Daiichi, Focus on Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine
properties.photo6_cap:
View from walkway that runs parallel to six reactor units Zaporozhzhia, with reactor 2 building on right.
Credit: Energoatom/Telegram
